title: Bengali Cuisine
hero_image_alt: Tangy Fish Curry with Rice and Rosogolla
short_description: Characterized by the use of mustard oil, panch phoron spices, freshwater fish, and world-famous milk-based sweets.
long_description:
Bengali cuisine, originating from West Bengal and Bangladesh, is the only multi-course tradition in the Indian subcontinent that follows a specific serving order similar to French cuisine (à la russe). It emphasizes the balance of sweet and spicy flavors and is renowned for its diverse use of freshwater fish and vast repertoire of milk-based desserts.

The staple food is rice and fish. The unique flavor profile comes from 'Panch Phoron'—a five-spice mix of fenugreek, nigella, cumin, black mustard and fennel seeds—and the pungent kick of mustard oil. A typical meal starts with a bitter preparation (Shukto), followed by lentils (Dal) and vegetables, then fish (Machh), meat, chutney, and finally, dessert (Mishti). The region is often called the 'Land of Sweets' (Mishti) for introducing Rasgulla and Sandesh to the world.

signature_dishes.name: Machher Jhol
signature_dishes.short_description: A light, flavorful stew of fish (typically Rohu or Katla) with vegetables, seasoned with turmeric and cumin.

signature_dishes.name: Kosha Mangsho
signature_dishes.short_description: Slow-cooked mutton curry with a thick, velvety dark brown gravy, rich in spices.
signature_dishes.serving_style: Main Course with Luchi or Paratha

signature_dishes.name: Shorshe Ilish
signature_dishes.short_description: Hilsa fish cooked in a pungent mustard paste gravy. A monsoon delicacy.

signature_dishes.name: Rosogolla
signature_dishes.short_description: Spongy cottage cheese balls soaked in light sugar syrup.

signature_dishes.name: Luchi-Alur Dom
signature_dishes.short_description: Deep-fried puffed bread made of refined flour served with spicy potato curry.

top_restaurants.notes: Fine dining restaurant serving authentic traditional Bengali buffet and thalis.

top_restaurants.name: Peter Cat
top_restaurants.notes: Famous for its Chelo Kebabs, a unique Indo-Iranian dish beloved by Bengalis.

top_restaurants.name: Oh! Calcutta
top_restaurants.notes: Reliable upscale chain for Bengali cuisine lovers.

street_food_highlights: Kathi Roll - Skewer-roasted kebab wrapped in paratha.
Phuchka - Bengali version of Panipuri, known for tangy tamarind water.
Jhal Muri - Spicy puffed rice snack.
festival_foods: Durga Puja: Bhog (Khichdi & Labra) served at Pandals.
Poila Baisakh (New Year): Elaborate fish platters.
best_months_to_visit_for_food: October (Durga Puja) for the festive feast vibe.
recommended_precautions_for_travellers: Be careful with fish bones. Mustard oil has a sharp taste that might be new to some.
how_to_order_guidelines: Courses are eaten in sequence: bitters -> vegetables -> fish -> meat -> chutney -> sweet.
cultural_significance: Food is an obsession in Bengal. Debates over the best Hilsa or Rosogolla are a cultural pastime. 'Adda' (informal gatherings) is incomplete without tea and snacks.
dining_etiquette: Fish is eaten with hands to carefully separate bones. Finishing the meal with sweets is mandatory.

top_places_to_experience.title: Kolkata
top_places_to_experience.summary: The culinary powerhouse of East India, inventing the Rosogolla and Kathi Roll.

suggested_itineraries: Kolkata Sweets Trail: North Kolkata (Sandesh) -> Central (Rosogolla) -> South (Mishti Doi).
